Minor spoilers for honey and clover, so be warned.
After the personal turmoil of an experience that was watching 3-gatsu no lion, I found myself needing more. As I have stated on another review, that you can look for, if you are interest for more in-depth thoughts, 3-gatsu has managed to become one of my favorite pieces of fictions. So it is only natural, that after that I would be looking for the authors other works, at worst to see how she has evolved as writer, at best to get a close experience. On that note, there was another highly regarded work from author umino chika,and the purpose of this review is to discuss it, honey and clover, and to make some assessments on her general writing style, by comparing it with her later work. Does it hold up to the lofty expectations I created for her, is it able to fulfill my dose of her endless sentimental style of storytelling, at least until her other work, becomes my favorite anime from 2018?


Youth, the age of the rose colored spring of life. That magic time where everything seemed possible and achievable. I am sure you have heard all this idealistic bullshit about the period, but maybe it sounds like that, when you are way older. This is show is basically a very earnest and heartfelt representation of this age. In here we see the coming of age of our 5 main characters, all offering their own unique spin and personal perspective on the topic. One aspect that helps to sell this portrayal is the setting where this takes in, not some high school but a freaking college. Yes, you heard it right, this does not take place in a generic high school as every school comedy ever, but instead in an art college to be more specific. This is important not only because this is the time period I am current living in, so the image of a bunch of broken young adults living together, and doing their best with limited money is immensely relatable to me, believe me it is. But it also adds so much to the story. There is the sense of urgency and importance to the characters conflicts you can only find it in this setting, acts like choosing a career and joining the workforce are right around the corner for this characters, which are life changing moments and decisions. It is a time of change, you can have to go to another town to get the college, find yourself living with completely new people, maybe even sustaining yourself, having lots of different and more serious concerns. It is no wonder that change is such a big issue for the characters themselves. And the show really commits to this representation of the period, there is such an immense degree of situations and emotions being presented, the search for meaning and direction in life, the friendships, the romance, the rejections, the insecurity, the separations, reencounters. And guess what they sell it hard on every emotion, the character’s interactions are so honest and endearing that the viewer itself starts seeing them as their friends and loves just to see them hang out together, it evokes the same feeling of having this unique and special group of friends. It may be melodramatic and annoying but those sure are valid and important feeling, we all felt at the time, we all though what we were going through, was the most important and serious thing ever. The variety in situations is also important, there is something for everyone to relate here, be it Takemoto aimlessness and search for a path in life, morita inability to let go of his past and connect with others, yamada failings in here romantic connections, Hagu trauma for her abuse as a child and how that affects her. There is something for everyone to grab that can relate and resonates deeply with their own experiences (which is kind of one of my main negative points). Not only our main characters add a lot to this, seeing the secondary character’s perspective can also be very enlightening. There is a duo of old teachers that observe Takemoto, to him the work he was making was a pointless and worthless representation of his lack of purpose in life. They themselves recognize it as such, and they love it for that, it leads them to the memories of their own younger selves, as they were dealing with the time, it might seem like though worthless period at the time but it is very precious to them as they grow older, they feel very nostalgic about it. Another aspect is how most older characters’ act, like nomiya and hanamoto, it is their older age and experience that leads them to be better at dealing with their issues and emotions that weight our mains, to the point they usually act for emotional support to them.


You know, many would think I am being facetious when saying that clover takes place at a time of grandiose changes in our characters’ lives, because pretty much nothing really changes that much since the start of this anime. The passage of time is acknowledging sure, days, months seasons and even years pass by, this story takes places during several years of our character’s lives. But the main core and dynamic of our main characters, their struggles and most of the background characters, still remains relatively unchanged by this story course. I have two ideas of why that is the case, one is that this is just laziness of the author, trying to keep the status quo, just to keep the story going as much as possible. But I still believe those are methodically planned and used to portray what I really believe is the main idea brought forward in this story. The main motifs this show used are the Ferris wheel, the main oppressive imaginery that seems to inhabit a lot of our characters imagenery, and the bicycle, (also that spinning cuck marker that I have no idea what it is) that is not only Takemoto means of escape, it is also an object that dominates his thoughts. Both of those show circular imagenery that points out to the cyclic nature of life, this show is portraying. No matter how much our characters struggle they also end up at approximately the same place, all in a never ending cycle, with only the feeling of regret for not accomplishing what they desire, at the end of the line. Takemoto is probably the biggest case for this, his literal journey is not only of searching for his true self as the characters in the show point out, by seeing how far he can go he wants to break this cycle, what path and decision in life he can do to actually make the change he want to make in the world, (his confession, finding a job) actually happen and getting rid of the uncertainty, his future has. Changing yourself in clover is not impossible though, both Takemoto and mayama have remarkable aspects of that, and this ties back to the topic of growing up. Mayama’s case is also really interesting, the guy at the start of the series is obsessed with the appearance of maturity, smoking, drinking being kind of reliable to his friends, just looking cool. He believes this is a sign of growing up, he will impress rika, the more mature woman he is in love with that, his insecurity holding him back to actually get closer to her. When he acknowledges the flaws in himself, and starts doing the best he can for her, regardless of any appearances, regardless of how pathetic he may end up looking in her eyes, Mayama finally gets it, he matures a little and finally starts breaking the cycle he is in. Takemoto also grows as a person, he finally stops worrying about grandiose questions like the meaning of life, no one is able to give him answers, he found the value of those around him, and can support the uncertainty of his future by sharing it with others. Not really related, but I wanted to say I love the idea of how hollow he feels being represented by this monotone noise he hears at his home, I swear I have felt the exact same thing, in regards to the noise my refrigerator makes. Facing change is frightening, you never know where it can lead, or how you will end in the process, it is something difficult to put forward, maybe as much as growing up, but finally acknowledging and making those things you so dearly desired happen is definitely worth it. Takemoto still got a sense of satisfaction out of his acts, despite the fact he really got rejected in the end, he made something great, and was proud of it regardless. This a stance and idea, I would love to be able to do myself, in my own life.


I do intend to use umino Chika (thanks for being alive and working btw) newer product, 3-gatsu, to shed some light into my bigger issues with this anime. While both were very similar in tone, the signatures of heavy handed sentimentality, the abrupt tone shifts, she is probably the only author, that blends so perfectly moments where I am close to tears, and moments where I am laughing my ass of, in a single episode. Like really both in 3-gatsu and in clover, chika is great at writing comedy. Never the comedy feels out of place, intrusive to the drama, or even downright insulting, like in shows like shitgatsu. And I just love how not mean spirited it is always, this sensation of this loveable characters teasing each other is just so heartwarming and perfect, I was sad to see this aspect take a back seat latter in the show. The variety in tones, and how perfectly she captures each one them is one of her greatest strengths as a writer, she is just so great at creating pathos and making it feel earned out of the most mundane situations. This is also complemented in clover by the usage of music, which was crucial for this anime. Half of what made most of the better moments in the anime work so well, was the complement of an atmospheric, and compelling soundtrack, some of the tracks in this conveyed the feeling of scenes, with the music alone. The decision of having dialogue and plot take a backset, for more atmospheric scenes, where the tracks would be the focus really paid off, making for some of the memorable and intense moments in this anime. Clover has one of my favorite soundtracks in anime, heck I could keep listening to it all day. But 3-gatsu no lion has a way narrower focus, it is first and foremost rei’s story, while clover shifts perspective between our 5 different main characters. And really the scope of themes clover has going for it is also way larger, there is an infinitude of themes with lots of characters adding their own little perspective to the mix, excluding sexuality, that is taboo in this show. But you know what, that variety usually does not work to the shows advantage, most of the themes and ideas being thrown around are not being explored in meaningful ways. Like for example, there is a segment when they go about, the feelings of loneness Takemoto is having, what comes out of it? A poetic monologue about how this is something everyone feels at certain moments in their lives, always coming and going, that is it. No insight or exploration of such a serious and important aspect of life. Ideas like these are being thrown around constantly, and not much of them gets the attention they deserve. This theme exploration is not entirely bad on itself, if anyone that is passing through those periods of life, can get one or two little insights about a personally important topic, but it still pales in comparison to 3-gatsu, which has a way more focused storyline and fully develops most themes it brings forward. Compared to 3-gatsu shows rei loneness, and how much it adds to the story and is explored, it also helps that 3-gatsu is way subtler about its set of themes, clover sometimes has those mentor older characters, explain the whole point the author is trying to make in length, which makes me think I am watching oregairu again. And that is never a good thing. Also this taking place in an art project, but rarely ever focusing on the creative process, value of art, or the mindset of artists is really a missed opportunity. Yes, I in general prefer 3-gatsu to clover, and maybe it all comes to me being kind of similar to rei as a person, only once before have I seen such a relatable character, that was a haunting and beautiful representation of what I was feeling at the moment, but I do find it have greater value and storytelling overall.


So would I recommend this show? Absolutely yes. If you are looking for a more mundane and heartwarming take on teenage life, especially if you are going through this period yourself, this is the anime for you. I am surprised this is in fact not loved for more people, it manages to portray so beautifully this turmoil of emotions, that make up a big part of our lives, with good character writing, and lots of important and resonating life lessons. I would really expect this to be even life changing for some. It may not be the perfect masterpiece, I found Umino Chika younger work to be, and this season may only conclude one-character arc, so not sure if the next season finishes the story, but I hardly found it to be unsatisfying as an ending. Clover is a wonderful journey; I will remember fondly for a long time. Also God bless Umino Chika now officially my new favorite mangaka. May she keep blessing us, with those amazing manga (which I have not seen any, just watched anime adaptations), that make me feel so happy, fulfilled and motivated, which will always be a safe heaven, and stop point, when I feel reality becomes a little too hard to handle. Thank you so much.

In life, there’s always moments of happiness. Happiness, in general, can be achieved quite easily; receiving an unexpected gift, having great success in your career, and most especially, falling in love. But have we once thought that every time happiness comes our way, there will always be someone around us that will be on the opposite side of the coin? Failure comes with success, bitterness come with love. These are bundled facts in life that no human being is immune to. In my first review, I’ll be talking about Hachimitsu to Clover or Honey and Clover. A series that tells the story about a groupof people that tasted both success and failure in life. Honey and Clover. What an ironic title for a show that gives off both happiness and bitterness.


Story:

Talking about the “main” story is hard because every main character have different goals and aspirations. Takemoto and his continuous journey to find himself, Morita and his path to revenge, Hagu and her desire in becoming a great artist, & Mayama and Yamada in their pursuit for the love of the ones they love *smirk*. These stories are all really interesting because they are so realistic. It tells the viewers throughout the series that not all things in life go how they want it to be. The sad reality that there will always be someone better than you, and that love can sometimes be one-sided. However, in spite of the “negative” side of the show, there’s this mysterious magic that appears almost after each depressing scenes. It feels like a figurative pinch in the heart. As I’ve said, a beautiful tale of happiness and sadness. You will feel happy and sad at the same time while holding back tears of... I don’t even know. There’s one time I felt sad and happy at the same time so it’s really difficult to describe the right feeling. A really good show if you want to feed birds at a park while feeling empty inside. Not a bad price to pay for an amazingly good show.


Characters:

	Because there are many main characters in the series, I will avoid talking about a specific character in general. So, yeah, I’ll start. 

In spite of my continuous bitching about the show’s sometimes depressing atmosphere, it might be hard to believe that every character in this series also have a fun and fluffy side to them as well.  Every character might (and WILL) send tears running down your cheeks, but always remember that these tears are not limited to only the emotional moments, they can also make you cry out tears of joy (A little bit of an overstatement, but you know what I mean) with all the really funny comedy. Some might love them, some may not, but you will surely get attached to them in just a couple of episodes throughout their long journey.


Animation:

	The animation for both series of Honey and Clover was done by J.C. Staff, famous for works such as Ano Natsu de Matteru, Golden Time, Nodame Cantabile, and my all time favorite anime: Eiken. The animation for this show is pretty standard compared to most of their show but that’s understandable because not much special effect is used. It’s a simple slife (slice of life) romance show. It doesn’t have bombastic scenes like Shana’s flames (Random tangent. J.C. Staff’s fire is probably the sexiest fire in current time. If KyoAni made water look sexy, J.C.’s selling point is fire. *points to Shana, Index, and Witch Craft Works*) or Nodame’s 3D orchestration so it’s pretty simple, though, not bad. I kinda hated the character designs but that’s a personal thing. It feels a little too shoujo/jousei-ish for my taste but its fine. As my policy goes, Even if the animation/character designs are bad, if the story is good, I’ll watch it. So, yeah, cool.


Sound:

	I don’t think I should be reviewing this section because personally, I don’t have confidence in my taste in music. I like music, but I don’t think I’m a good judge in this field. So, don’t hold it against me if my opinion in music is that bad. Now that’s out of the way, maestro, music! 

Since I rarely listen to whole anime soundtrack, I’ll bring this down on the actual music that was used in the show. I’ll start with the OPs. OP 1 was really amazing. Nakushita yakusoku wa hoshi…. Enough on my weeabo karaoke. lol. Anyway, that OP was really good not only because of the music but also because of the visuals. What a really fun foodporn. I never once skipped that OP which made me sad once it got replaced. I wish the OP stayed the same throughout the whole series. You know, like what they did with Log Horizon 2’s OP; new foodporn but same music. In regards to the music used on the show, I can’t quite remember it except the mellow piano version of the OP during emotional moments, then that wacky party like tune used during funny moments. Those ones were really well used. Though repetitive, it fits the moment perfectly and adds to the overall feel of the show. And allow me to make a confession, I rarely watch EDs (I watch a show’s ED once then that’s it). With that said, I don’t really have anything to say with the ED since I don’t remember it, I just remember a Ferris wheel and that’s it. lol. In regards to the dub in both sides, I haven’t seen the English dub yet so I’ll limit this in the japo dub side. Since I can’t understand much Japanese, I’d probably say it’s a good dub. Hiroshi Kamiya, one of my favorite seiyuu played as Takemoto. Kamiya always has this weird accent but in Honey and Clover he used the dialect from Osaka and it was just amazing.


Verdict:

	Now, after pulling random numbers out of my ass (8.6 for story, 8.4 for characters, 7.3 for animation, 8.2 for music, and 9 for overall enjoyment), I’ll gladly give Honey and Clover with an overall score of [b]8.3[/b]. Honey and Clover is a show that really excels in making you feel like crap in the rain, but tells you that once the rain stopped, you’ll be mixed in the water, evaporate, become rain, fall in a river, then be made as a drinkable water (What the fuck did I just made up?). Uhhhh, If I somewhat gave you a trauma because of that scenario, feel free to kill me in my sleep. Anyway, back on topic. Yeah, Honey and Clover is an amazing show, if you haven’t seen it yet, you have my full-blown recommendation. Go on, watch it, but just be warned of the void in your heart that will come once you finish it.


Alternate Anime Recommendation:

	For alternate anime recommendation, why don’t you try Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo? Both shows are pretty similar in the “You’re shit. You have no talent. Go die in a fire.” section. Though, slight spoiler, Sakurasou has too many depressing moment. If Honey and Clover pinches your heart, Sakurasou will stab your heart. Both have pretty decent comedy too. The romance in both series is really unsatisfying but cute. And they’re both made by J.C. Staff too.


You can also try Nagi no Asukara if you want too. Though not as depressing as Honey and Clover, Nagi no Asukara have some rather sad moments as well that might make you shed a tear. Another important thing to point out is that both series have love n-gons (not just triangles. Not just squares. They have too many to even count) that went completely nowhere.


	Well, that’s it for me, thanks if you read all of that. I might do this again if I have the chance to. If you like it, feel free to send me a PM if you want me to review other shows. I’ll see you (whoever’s reading this) around. Bye-nara!

I first picked up Honey and Clover one school break during my college days, during the days when all I can think about is friendship/love/pressure to succeed/family woes, and then I found an image of myself in the story. This is how Honey and Clover succeeds to become a heart-warming slice of life series, I think it gave me a glimmer of hope despite the fleeting nature of youth, HnC assures me that you can make wonderful memories even when youth is long gone.
The pace of HnC is slow, but relaxing. It is animation in poetry form, the details and soft colours paint a character'smood or scenario and the feelings slowly flood your senses. Then there is the calming voice of Takemoto speaking in the background and his narration becomes the frame of the painting, piecing everything together. Beautiful and carefully hand-picked soundtracks by the mangaka herself are laced into the anime and I believe the songs were chosen for their lyrics which never fail to reflect the innermost emotions the featured characters are going through that moment in time. Just with these few elements, I'm constantly amazed and blown away by the anime.


But the story is what keeps you on your toes, despite the slower pacing, the twists and circumstances of every character captures you and sometimes what they experience is an incident I can relate to and I find myself cheering/crying for the character. Humour is often used to balance the mood, just the way we would in real life, and some the characters will send you in tears, while laughing. Because...


The characters in the story are so diverse and well-developed you will love them all, if not you'd love at least a few of them. There is the timid but talented Hagu-chan who conquers her lack of courage through her emotive paintings, nice guy Takemoto is a good friend to all but lonely at times when his willpower is shaken, Morita is a crazy blitz you can't help laughing at but his mysterious nature also pulls you in, Mayama the big brother torn between woes of loving and being loved, Yamada the naive girl who is crazy for Mayama and constantly has her heart broken, and of course Shu-chan the caretaker who watches over the group and sometimes nostalgia creeps up to him and he find himself missing his good friends from college. These are the primary characters, but revolving each of them are many more characters so different and colourful, you may just feel something familiar with any one of them too.


I'm not gonna lie, Honey and Clover remains one of my favourite series in print and motion form, and I've lost count of the number of times I re-watched the series so I may sound like one of those fans who will protect the series at all cost. However, while some may love the action-packed theme anime series out there, I believe some of us are also searching for that one anime that speaks to our inner emotions. When I re-watch HnC now, long past those youthful college days, whatever I have felt years ago while watching the series I can still feel them strongly if not even more strongly than before. It is a timeless art piece in the anime genre and as it sums up in one of my favourite quote from the series - 


“As time passes, the day will come when everything will fade to memories. But those miraculous days, when you and I, along with everyone else, searched together for just that one thing, will continue revolving forever somewhere deep in my heart, as my bittersweet memory.”

The key to happiness is something we humans long to find in our short time in this earth. It's something that can't be seen nor touched, but we want to find it. A way we find this key is to go through our lives searching it, but like a four-leaved clover, it takes some fumbling around the grass to find it. In Honey and Clover, our main characters do just that, fumbling around life to find that key to happiness while life keeps going forward, no matter if they find it or not. 
While this is a story of not battles to save the world,nor about a meaningless crush on the transfer student, but a story about a battle, the battle we all have inside of us to find our what is truly our own unique meaning here in life and the love that while bittersweet, it taught us about love.  This story is relateble to all of us as we follow a group of art college students going to life looking for their key to happiness and the battle that ranges inside us as we go through our lives looking for that key.


The art of the anime is very compatible to the story in more ways than your usual anime. While most anime has the normal bold look, this anime uses a watercolor look to it that makes it soft looking, which really goes with the flow of the anime, which is slow paced.


For the music, it uses mostly slow rock or some pop that really fits with the theme and flow of the story. It uses a lot of music, that ranges in types, from rock to jazz, but while it seems to be a lot, they all go with the story's flow.


Characters are a really important thing for any story, anime or manga. They are what projects the story's feeling and flow. If the characters don't show anything, it's just a boring book that doesn't capture our attention.Our main characters show a lot of significance to the story, because without them, Honey and Clover would not made any sense without their feelings to the story.

Mayama; playing the role of the cool, intelligent type. He’s always shown smoking and looking off into the distance, giving advice to the other characters,taking care of himself finacially. Of course he's not perfect, jokes are made throughout the anime about his stalker-like admiration for Rika. He’s a bit of both: on one hand, a calm and collected upperclassman, but on the other hand, obsessive and overprotective. 

Ayumi; In the group, she's the motherly character, helping and caring for her friends. While she may look like a beautiful young woman, on the inside she's like a baby. Completely innocent, she continues to strive for a love that would never work out, but because she's hesitant to cut off that stem, she continues to hurt and not move on. 

Hagu; while her character's look and act is interesting, her character begins to make a bit more sense when you think how she was brought up, and, more importantly, her love for art. Raised in a enclosed environment,  she was always a distant child, it’s as if she lived in a completely different world, and didn't bother learning the basics of socializing. As a result of that, she looks like a child when compared to her classmates, and she needs someone like Shuu to take care of her like a father. 

Morita; My god... this guy can bring comic relief in any situation. However, he also serves as an important part of the group, he's the glue to hold them all together. While he's the "idiot” type, he's surprisingly very mature and perspective. He’s a bit like Mayama, he helps the other characters out by giving advice and giving them the harsh reality at times. 

Takemoto; the everyman character. An interesting guy because he was normal, but it was his ordinary, relatable personality that let his story made what Honey and Clover is. Even though he has no unique traits or abilities to drive him forward, he entered art school, but has no clue as to what he wants to do after he graduates. Because of this and other stress in his life, he built a massive tower, broke it down, and then ride half way across Japan and back.


The theme of “moving forward”;the flow of time, moving forward always. And the four leafed clover, representing the one “thing” that they were all searching for. In this case, that thing was something more important than a clover, like love, or happiness, but hard to find. Because we are all battling that battle and finding our clovers, it just a matter of falling on the grass and looking for our happiness.


I enjoyed this anime very much, it made me think about myself but also made me smile as I watched. I suggest this for all who want to enjoy themselves but also reflect on their lives. 


Story: 10

Art:10

Sound:10

Character:10

Enjoyment: 10


OVERALL: 10

My favorite genre of anime has usually been either slice-of-life or romance. This is no exception. It is one of the best romance anime you’ll probably ever see. What makes it so good, is that all the human emotions in it… they seem so real.
Story
Love is the main part of the story. Any type, you name it: confused love, selfish love, unrequited love, and just plain love. This is such a dramatic anime, but what happens to the characters makes it very realistic. Frustrations of feeling alone, the pressure of everyone around you, the anxieties of where you’ll be in life, are all things thecharacters have to deal with as the progress through the story. It’s one of the sweetest romance stories I’ve come across, actually. There’s no fanservice, rarely a peverted thought. Only the heart-wrenching and bittersweet notion of love.


Art


The art, I thought was gorgeous. The animation went long so smoothly, and I loved the color choices, everything looked like watercolors. I also really liked the way the eyes looked, especially of Hagu. They were very pretty an dmade her look doll-like.


Sound


The sound was great. The ending and opening themes were nice, even though I liked the first ending better than the second ending. I still liked both. The background music was sweet-sounding, a lot of piano music was used of the opening.


Characters


The characters are all believable.  I ended up disliking some and rooting for others (which is partly why the ending left me dissatisfied though it was predicable). Yamada’s unrequited love for Mayama was understandable, but irritating that he didn’t love her back. I realize you can’t force yourself to love someone. But maybe this is one of the realistic aspects; there are not always happy endings. Anyway, I liked most of the characters. Morita and Yamada were my favorites, I think. Morita is just so unique. It makes me wonder what goes on in his mind. As for Yamada, I felt sorry for her and I kept wanting her to end up with Mayama throughout the series, even though it was easy to see early on that it was sort of hopeless. Takemoto is basically the protagonist, since he narrates the most, even though the story doesn’t focus entirely on him. 


Enjoyment


Okay, this took me a while to get through. I started it around in December and I’m just now finishing it in May. Still, just because I took it slowly doesn’t mean it was boring for me. I really did want to finish it, and I’m glad I did because it was a thoroughly  enjoyable series.


Overall


This was a very great series, portraying realistic relationships between ultimately believable and likeable characters. I loved it.

Ill try to make this review short and straight to the point.
The story is simple, yet it allows for amazing develop. It has a great balance between comedy and drama, i found myself laughing at one moment then crying the next. As for the characters, they are some of the most memorable characters in the anime. It is almost impossible not to relate or sympathize with the characters. They each have their own flaws, their own motives and a very realistic personality. In short the characters were three-dimensional. As for the art, it was calming and serene and fit the mood and atmosphere of theshow perfectly. The OST was good, but sadly nothing stood out. Though the opening video is one of the most unique and creative opening I've ever seen.  Overall, i didn't enjoy this show, i loved it-i fell heads over heels for it. Only a few animes left me begging for more, the characters and their interactions, truly unforgettable.


Now time to talk about why u may not like it, AT FIRST.

As stated previously the plot is simple, don't expect much. Some people may find it extremely boring at first, but bare with it, as the characters will soon draw u into the show and completely immerse you into their world. Finally, Hagu. Yes shes ludicrously short, but aren't there short people in the real world too, so why can't there be one in anime? Also, whats wrong with her being the main character's love interest. She's still a human, and a very cute and talented one. Her looks, first drew Takemoto in. She was unlike anything he'd ever seen and every human to some degree is interested in something new. Finally, her talent was revealed and bam Takemoto fell in love. Takemoto, as shown later in the show, is someone lost, unable to determine what to do in the future, but as for Hagu she already knows. It is because of Hagu's talent and preparedness, that caused Takemoto and Morita to become infatuated and enamored with her (morita's side story is told during the second season). She was Takemoto's inspiration and in Takemoto's eyes a person to look up to and thus Hagu was someone he had to hold close in his life. As for Hagu's behavior early in the show, simply put she's awkward around people. Luckily she begins to feel more comfortable around the rest of the characters and, and becomes a "normal" character. 


In conclusion, Honey and clover is definitely a 10/10. with flaws too small to notice and a cast as memorable as your first anime.

(This is a review on the entire Honey and Clover franchise, including the OVAs)
Why is love so bittersweet?
Love, friendship, and jealousy: a simple love story that focuses on the growth and development of an individual from adolescence to adulthood. That is Honey and Clover in a nutshell. Honey and Clover revolves around the daily lives of five college students whose lives are changed when love gets in the way of their affairs. The story starts off, rather slow, with spontaneous comedic outbursts and a nonexistent plot. It is at this point where I wanted to drop it; however, once the fourth episode come around, thethemes of this show become much more apparent, and toward the thirteenth episode of the first season, the comedy aspect of the show starts to fade, eventually taking a backseat in season two.


Honey and Clover truly is a slice of life show. It depicts the many hardships every person goes through as they grow up--lighthearted, funny, sentimental moments we want to treasure in our hearts forever, and the bitterness of unrequited love, jealousy, and betrayal, that we try so hard to forget. These conflicts give a sharp, yet pragmatic tone that resonates deep in the viewers' hearts. 


In today's industry, shows usually rely on useless plot devices to move along the story. This is not the case in Honey and Clover. During each episode, the writer effortlessly tells a tale that is loosely held together by the romance each character wants in their lives. We see each character grapple with love, dreams, and friendship. We see their internal struggles presented to us through raw emotion, which in turn invokes nostalgic memories from the viewer of their childhood days when things were considered brighter and more colorful. The characters in Honey and Clover in one word can be best described as diverse. Honey and Clover decided to do away with the common character archetypes and instead deliver a cast that is realistically simple and relatable.


The music and animation productions in this show is top notch, which is to be expected for a show that revolves around the arts. My favorite soundtracks from this show included a few of the insert songs found through the course of the show, Yamanai Ame, and the opening and ending tracks from both seasons.


If you are looking for a down-to-earth slice of life show, look no further. Honey and Clover is one of the best shows in its genre. It is a show that brilliantly captures human emotion and adversity. It is, without a doubt, one of the best you will ever find.

This story tells us about the struggling of youth. Youth that supposed to be the best phase of human’s life turns out to be not so sweet. In this series we’ll see the character’s struggle to express their feeling, to find what they’re really want, to accept a bitter defeat, and face the ugly side of love. 
While the common Shoujou animes are quietly predictable - the female leading star will get her dream, going out with the leading man, Hachikuro give a hard cold fact that you can’t always get what you want. Hachikuro’s target audience is the young female adults. The story itself makes us reflects on the life we lead in the real world.


Amazing story line, great characterization, beautiful visual and awesome awesome theme songs. Unpredictable ending. Even though the flow of story is rather constant and simple, but it didn’t make the audience bored. Hachikuro is the best shoujo anime I’ve ever seen.

"A six-tatami room with no bath, ten minutes walk from the college. Built twenty-five years ago, rent 38,000 yen. The walls are thin and hardly soundproof. All residents are students. The morning sun is bright since it faces east.-Takemoto Yuta.”
Low profile Yuuta Takemoto is undoubtedly just an ordinary architecture student with inferiority complex that runs away from home after his mother married a man who’s totally opposite of his late beloved father. He decided to live in an old creaky apartment where he met his two friends Takumi Mayama and Shinobu Morita who are also belong to the architecture department in their school. 
Takemoto andHaguWhen she met the cute, lovely and talented Hagumi Hanamoto whose in fact a niece of their teacher, he knew that it was love at first sight. But it seems pretty hard for him to convey his feelings towards her because he found out that his mysterious, money-loving and hyper-active friend Morita has also an eye for Hagu-chan.Ayumi and Mayama. 


On the other hand, Ayumi Yamada, whose expertise in pottery is truly incomparable, has a long time feelings for our timid and serious-type Takumi Mayama who loves a different, weak and lonesome buttered woman older than him. To add knots on all love triangles this story have, a resident womanizer from Mayama’s work named Nomiya was showing an interest on Yamada which makes Mayama a little bit insecured and over-protective onto her. Is it jealousy? 


Follow the different lives of these five art students with their dignified teacher as they strive to reach their dreams and learn the shining shimmering lessons of their youthful lives unveiling their true feelings while sorting out their own love triangles.


Honey and Clover is a simple classic tale which has proven to us that you don’t need to have flashy and high-tech illustrations and elements to bring a nice and self-relating story that’ll captures everyone’s heart and mind.

I recently decided to rewatch Honey and Clover after having experienced unrequited love, heartbreak, and uncertainties about the immediate future. I felt also that I should rewatch and watch some anime dealing with college, while I’m still in it myself. 
I will skip over a synopsis since there already is one. As for talking about the story itself, it is slice of life to its core. Rarely, even in the same genre, can you find a story so mature, realistic, and moving. Few anime deal so much and so heavily with unrequited love, college, and the uncertainties of life. The story is able to showit all and more, as it takes along on its journey, that feels all too real and relatable. Now I will not lie, especially the first few episodes are slow, and it takes a while to really get into the show. But, if you keep with it, you’ll slowly start finding yourself enjoying it, and loving it—relating to it. We must realize that this show is at its core is slice of life, and it does just that showing us the realities of life and all that comes with it. It many ways it is slow, but it’s also fast.


One thing that you must realize, and probably will, is that the show is very philosophical. While I am always writing down quotes from anime, and other media that I watch or read (because I do love quotes) I always find myself writing down much more on a second viewing, and boy did I write a lot of them out. They’re very nice, but you do notice every once in a while how many times the characters dig in and think deeply about life, among other issues. It’s kind of like the show is talking to itself and also talking to us. 


Honestly, the characters make up some of the best parts of the anime. Their connections to each other, their feelings, their lives—it all goes to make them feel real and relatable, but distinct and unique. There is character development, and lots of it—as they move along trying to find themselves, their feelings, and thinking about everything that’s gone on. The characters are really well done. Now I notice many people disliking Hagu, and how she’s small and everything, it got me at first as well, but you get used to it, or should. 


The art is unique, but not rare. If you’ve seen similar jousei anime/manga like Nodame Cantabile they seem to share a similar feel and style, but it’s also different from it. I ended up enjoying the art style, and felt that overall it had good quality to it. 


The music is very well done. The first OP is startling and stays with you. I liked almost the entire soundtrack, and the music is distinct enough that it sounds out and you can recognize it and feel connected, without it being overpowering. Though maybe they use a few of the same tracks a lot, but it’s not overpowering—mainly when you recognize it you realize what the anime is trying to convey at that moment, and the song become more memorable since it is distinct and is used more than once. 


My first viewing I watched it dubbed, my second subbed. I can’t say if I prefer one over the other. They’re both good in my opinion, and you can’t go wrong with either one. I felt that for the most part the voices on both dub and sub matched up well with the characters. 

The ending to the first season was well done. While a bit perhaps a bit of a cliffhanger, I can forgive it completely since there is a second season. But it also was a satisfying close to the first seasons as well, had it ended here I would have been a bit disappointed, but also strangely ok. I felt the same way at the end to the second season.


As for my enjoyment of this anime, I really did enjoy it. I was able to relate to the characters, feel their struggles, and more. If anything I’ve enjoyed it more my second viewing since I’m older now and basically the same age as many of the characters in the anime, at least those in college anyways. In many ways I’ve watched it again at just the right point in my life. Did I find all the answers to my life? No, but to quote the anime “who cares about an answer? There’s nothing like that to begin with.” I have to say I loved the quotes, and was able to get many of them. It was very enjoyable.


One of my favorite genres is slice of life, and I hold this up as one of the towering standards of the genre that everyone should watch. Sure many other anime in the genre might be “better” – Nodame Cantabile, Natsume Yuujinchou, but I think that Honey and Clover deserves a spot in the must watch category for slice of anime, or just anyone who has experienced unrequited love, uncertainty, college, or life.


Overall, I like honey and clover, and recommend watching it. 


Of note, I typically don’t rate anime—which you will see if you look at my list, but it forces me to rate it to post this review, so I have thought about it what rating I should and have thus accordingly given it. But scores aren’t always everything, though. I say that…

Remember the time when Honey and Clover sucked ? Neither do i ! This is easiest one of my favorite series of all time. 
This review is about the two series (Honey and Clover I & II) and it's one of those stories where you get an overdrama around things, everything that could go wrong happens and enloved people never get reciprocal feelings. But at the same time there is lots of commedy, as people tend to laugh at their disgrace and others. It is not one of that shows that will bore you, it's rewatch value is very high, the plot has lots oftwists, character development is superb, it is not just  your cheap romance you're used to have ! It is that deep ! And it takes you to many situations where you can trace a parallel in your life, identify yourself with characters and/or situations , think about life itself and so on...


Sometimes you can get mad by characters decisions , but as the plot develops you'll understand/accept their decisions and by the end...you'll notice that there really wasn't any other better way to reach that result...it's just like in real life... there're no such things as fairy tales... you can't really force someone that you love, to love you, if that person loves someone else... it's hopeless no matter how hard you try, because when people love, people get blind, and it is no use for you to try to dismiss that spell. That people alone has to open its own eyes and realize the painfull truth.


Honey and Clover has a priceless charm as it is more dramatic than romantic and it is full of commedy, but as i stated before, it is not boring, it keeps your attention in an interesting way full of plot twists and surprises... and the grand finale... i bet it will make you love this series forever.

An anime that in my opinion, college students can relate to.
Struggling to pay for the things you need, trying to meet deadlines, letting your friends be your refuge and strength, and finding what you want to do with your life.
Though many would disagree, I liked the art of the anime. It kind of had a realistic touch which reflected the story rather well, which I find to be important in an anime. It also had its comical art of snooze bubbles and little souls escaping from the mouth which gave the artwork character.
I can still sit here and play the song in my head whensomething funny is about to happen in the anime. It kind of makes me giggle sitting here thinking about it. Once the tune starts up, you know you're going to be laughing in the matter of seconds\n\n
The characters were pretty well rounded. There were many characters to relate to, a workaholic, crazy characters, characters graduating from college, even characters struggling to find their identity. Because of these characters I have been able to say I'm not alone, true, they aren't real, but things could always be worse and some times I take their thoughts and approaches on life and work off of that. So this series is very easy to relate to.\n\n
Overall a very enjoyable anime, VERY funny when Morita-senpai is in the picture. Very realistic in the way people think and strive to make it in this world.

With this being my first review, so please go easy on me, and this will be covering both season one and two of Honey and Clover. Being a college student, it’s a nice change of pace watching an anime about college kids as opposed to the usual, yet enjoyable, high school stories. At some point everyone will reach the point where they sit down and ask themselves, “Just what do I want to do with my life.” Honey and Clover follows the life of 6 college students and 1 university professor. This anime deals with a lot of realistic issues such as graduation, finding ajob, path to adulthood, integration into society, relationships, and money.


Let’s start off with the story; the story can be a little slow at time but it’s all about character development. As stated before it deals with more of realism as opposed to happy anime fun time, not that that’s a bad thing. The story of college students dealing with graduation, making friends for life, dealing with their families, venturing off into the world of adulthood, and the ongoing shenanigans of a genius pretty much sums up what to expect from the story. I can’t really type much else without giving major spoilers.


Moving onto the characters; I can go on and on about the characters but I’ll try to keep it brief. If there is one thing everyone can agree on is that, but first and foremost MORITA is currently one of my favorite characters ever. All of the characters complement each other well and help in the development of the story. My current rating for characters is an 8; it would be a 10 except for the fact that there is one little girl whom I completely detested. A certain 7 year old looking college student was the only character who didn’t make any progress in developing as a human being. Granted her presence contributed to the story, but as a character herself she showed little to no development. She is an 18 year old in a 7 year old body with the mind of a shy 5 year old. I can tolerate a loli here and there, but Hagu is just too much. Everyone else really evolved over the course of the story, and Morita-san was hilarious, loveable, and just plain awesome. I wish I could meet some like Morita san in real life.


The artwork in this anime was so so, but I will say this, the background was really well done and the character design was above average. The sound can get a little annoying at times since they have a lot of scenes where the characters just walk around doing something while some sad Japanese song plays in the background. Actually if memory serves it happens in almost every episode.


Overall Honey and Clover was a very enjoyable anime, and it really made me think about my future. At one point or another we all are going to have to make the decisions these fine young men and woman and hagu half to make regarding our futures. Hopefully for us it won’t have to deal with most of the drama though.


Ending thoughts:  Morita-san = awesome, Hagu = horrible character, and real world = sucks

Readers beware:Excessive use of mature language.If you are allergic to different opinions to yours then sod off or i'm bringing out the hammer.
With that outta the way let's see what's what.If you have eyes,which i pressume you have since you're here,the synopsis is somewhere here on MAL so i won't bother with that at all.I've wasted enough of my time watching the damn anime,i refuse to waste some more.
And we begin,rather confusingly,with the opening song.That's the first thing that hits your screen after all so let's go with that.It's rubbish.Plain and simple rubbish.This is the opening of an anime and what they show you issome food either dancing or humping or whateva..I've seen many shit in my life but this trumps it all easily.As for the song being used?That's like listening to the mumblings of a child who got hold of a bottle of scotch and drank it all in one sitting and then telling you all about it's kindergarden adventures and how nobody loves him/her and is all alone and life is terrible and my ice cream melted and SHUT THE FUCK UP ALREADY..Dear mf lord!


And when you go past the first boss that is the opening song you are presented with one of the most ridiculous and horrific animations ever.If we were talking about DMC or even Ebichu it would be ok.That's supposed to be a somewhat serious down to earth anime and it looks like a fucking joke.It's not DMC bad but for a 2005 anime this looks like a washed out corpse.And don't think that as eps go by the animation gets any better cause it doesn't.In fact there are times where the animation is falling down a cliff.But hey this is heartwarming so the animation doesn't nee............Wait...What?What did you say?The animation what?Again if it's something like DMC made for fun then yes.If you're going for an anime that is all about a deep story then the animation HAS to be top notch.Did you ever go to a fancy restaurant and they served you a dish that looks like someone's ear infection?I guess not unless you count food from a canteen top of the pops.I can understand low budget issues but the only time it looked good was when you were shown stills but the motion itself is rigid and limited.


And onto the story.It’s about a group of college students,mostly in arts,and how they deal with romance,friendship and misfortune.On paper this sounds interesting..But it so isn't!


First off the way you present the story or stories in this case is the A and the Ω.Cause on paper things sound ok but on screen not so much.It tries to tell many stories at once and fails miserably,much like Greece's economy.The end result is that this feels like 2 animes botched together in a hurry by someone who doesn't like anime or botching that much.The stories or these 2 animes don't fit,they don't match and they certainly don't have any effect whatsoever to each other.Let me give you a perfect example of what i'm on about.


Yuuta lives the simple life of an art student,struggling to make ends meet all the while dealing with his weird as fuck roommate,Shinobu..But then out of the blue comes a surprise in his life when his art teacher brings his cousin’s daughter and talented young woman named Hagumi to class.....What?Sorry i got that wrong..It's not that,it's the story of Ayumi a pottery student who has the hots for a man who stalks a widow......What the fuck is wrong with me today..This is about Shinobu and his brother getting back their father’s company..Basically what happened here was that many people gathered with ideas and because they were bored and wanted to be done with it they threw the whole lot in the pot and made a green potato mush garnished with sausages and crepes...And if my description doesn't sound much,you should watch it and see for yerselves what a big mess they made of the storytelling.I cannot put it into words just how bad it is.But i'll give it a go nevertheless.


Let's go for them characters now and dive deep into the sea of misery that is this cast.


Let’s start with Hagu,an 8-year-old girl who is actually 18 as we're told.Now i should stress that not only she looks like a child,but the thing is that she also acts like a child with plus the social issues of a grown up and the social insecurity.It would have been so much better and would make so much more sense if they had just said she was a child,except for the minor detail that one of the protagonists,Takemoto,is in love with her and that would spoil the story they already had.


Speaking of Takemoto,he has to be the most boring character in the anime.Apart from the said romance with the 8yr old he has nothing going for him.He feels like an extra in his own freaking story.Let me run this past you.Someone who goes to school and graduates IS NOT a story.It's betime story at best.Someone who fails because of his unwillingness but somehow gets his shit together and then graduates to become something is a story..And an interesting one at that.There's no character growth to be found here.Yuuta’s story is your basic trip to graduation promised land.And even his supposed feelings for the midget don't make it better,cause Hagu is by no means an interesting character.And as for their "relationship"?That makes no blind bit of difference cause....Spoilers so i won't get into that.Let's say it ends up with some huge hints of pedophilia..Some like this sort of stuff you know.That's why some people thought it was cute and life changing and down to earth...Pedophilia..Makes for some interesting anime.This should be the slogan for most of the reviews actually.


Then we have Ayumi and her love conquests which include half the men in Japan.That is to hide here love for the man who is friendzoned by a widow.But her story is the most interesting one in the whole anime weirdly but it falls flat because they make such a heavy use of melodrama it ends up being reduced to a ridiculous story of i can't get past my crush i shall ruin my life and commit suicide.


These characters are poorly developed.This is just a story of emotionally immature people made for emotionally immature people who can't handle life and always cry and moan about how life is unfair and cruel cause their love interest doesn't give a single fuck...Οh boohoo..Romantic comedy my hairy ass.Yes it does have some hilarity spread here and there,but it only serves as a shortcut to depression and suicidal avenue crossing the lovesickjunkies street.I've never seen such an example of people going out of their way to stay depressed.Unless we're talking about kids,but even kids grow out of it and go on.This lot doesn't do moving on.


And it's not just the characters.It's the way we're told about the story of these characters.It's also the use of music.Music if used right can convey and enhance the emotion in a scene or a dialogue.It's not something you use in massive doses otherwise you end up on the wrong side of the track.And that's the case here.Almost every dialogue or monologue is accompanied by sentimental music.This makes the scenes overdramatic when they don't need to be.


And then we have the way the story is fed to us the viewers.Here we stumble upon the biggest issue of all.If you happen to read any review you'll find that everyone says the same thing like a broken cassete player.That the greatest qualities are found in the form of inner monologues that tell us everything about what a character is thinking and feeling.Yeah...If used correctly again yes..But notice now the key to this sentence...TELLING.


These characters are telling us how they feel,not showing us.Now picture this in your head.If you take the sound down all the way to 0 in the monologues,would the characters convey the same feelings?Would it show in their expressions how they feel that given moment?The answer to that is no.


Now that is called lazy writing.It completely renders any scene devoid of meaning.In other words it's how powerful visually and intense a scene can be even if there is no dialogue at all.Anyone can draw a scene by telling us about the scene.But showing us?That's the shit right there.


Now i won't reccomend it to anyone.But if you want to watch it and draw your own conclusions that's fine by me.

I enjoyed this series. At the time, I was in the last semester of my graduate school and the uncertainty of the future that Takemoto was going through towards the end really spoke to me. 
Some issues: the comedic segues were at times rocky and the men chasing after an adolescent-looking girl is a little troubling.
However, the series is at it's strongest when it focuses on the internal life of Takemoto, the earthy protagonist we can relate to in contrast to Hagu's ethereal nature.
The metaphor of the bicycle turning and (SPOILER ALERT AHEAD) the ending scene with Takemoto professing his love to Hagu is justbeautiful.\n\n
He expresses his love from a place of such strength. Having just completed his spiritual journey (bike riding to the top of Japan), he knows himself better and knows that regardless of the outcome, he has worth and he has to express his love for Hagu. This is an incredibly mature character study. When he says I love you and she says thank you, it leaves me breathless. If the show ended here, it would still be a great ending. However, I REALLY LIKE part two.\n\n
(See my review for Honey and Clover II after you've finished).

This anime has to be one of the best slice of life animes I've ever seen. It does not have a fancy story or overly complex characters, but still, it charms you in a way I cant properly explain. 
The story basically revolves around the typical love polygon we usually see in those types of anime, its characters not deeply developed and their background remaining mysterious until the end. Pretty plain, uh? No. The development of the story, the relations between its characters and the narrations, oh the narrations, almost all the times poetical, all of these factors contributing to an impressive experience watching ananime that had not caught my attention until reading some reviews. This anime is about youth, about college, about doubts on the future in a moment of our lives when we are usually lost and thinking about what are we going to do with our lives: our adolescence. I would definitely recommend this to anyone between the ages of 17 to 25, the story will surely touch your heart in an interesting way. This is a must!

...yourself... unable to leave everything behind...
Story (9.5): This anime is one of a few that have a great equilibrium between lighthearted laughs and a very deep and thuoghtful atmosphere. It's not just a drama, but a real approach to life, to it's questions, it's fear, it's pains and confusions. From the youth uncertainities of your own path and reasons to be, to the deeper ghosts of life like, attachments and fears that keep you from walking, learning the true meaning of love and facing an imperfect world. The only reason I didn't give it a 10, I'll admit is personal; at some point only oneof the character's story took too much importance, leaving me wanting to have more from the others.


Art (9): The art is very original and different from the stereotype, which is nice, althought, in the attempt to make Hagu extremely "kawai", she looked to me a bit Candy Candyish..., considering their good humor, I wouldn't doubt that's what they were trying to achieve. I specially loved how well the facial expressions conveyed each character's temperament and emotions.


Sound (10): Ahh, it's been a while since i've enjoyed an ending so much, both endings have just the perfect lyrics and feeling. And, hear this, you get to have an amazing plus because there are many episodes that include well thought songs to go with important moments, it reminded me of Mahou Tsukai ni Taisetsu na Koto: Natsu no Sora's style. I actually looked up for the OST, sad enough, the OST doesn't include all this songs D: (random comment, I know).


Character (10): What I enjoy the most about slice-of-life, is the way characters really tend to be from flesh and bones, and H&C really achieved this well, we not only have a nice variety of characters, but each one of them has a very unique personality and ghost to deal with, you really get to feel empathy, at least with one of them. Even Morita-san, that could have simply be the random guy in other animes, was perfectly well executed, as the socially awkward loner, that loves deeply, but deals with the world in the most quirk of ways, I'll admit, I was just waiting to finish this anime to add him to my favorite characters list, there should be more free spirits in anime like him.


Enjoyment (10): If it took me a while to finish it, it was only because I restrained myself to watch it all at once, because I didn't wanted it to end. So, this is one of those stories that you'll laugh, cry, get angry and happy with the characters.


Overall (10): If you like to think about life itself, this anime is for you, if you like a nice slice-of-life, or enjoy to have a mixture between drama and comedy/randomness, you really should check it out, this anime really leaves you thinking after each episode is done and perhaps, lets you experience that fuzzy warm feeling inside, when you discover something new or that perhaps, you had fogotten. If you're looking simply to sit back and relax though, well, H&C might not be the right anime for that mood, as it gets pretty tense and serious at some episodes.

This review is for the both shows. 
Hachimitsu to Clover or Honey and Clover is at least for me, the anime that gets closest to the reality. Literally there will be here one character that you will identify with .. personally i think i'm like the main character of this show .. and this is why this show can be so interesting. 
I mean .. in the normal romance we see the main characters getting in love and everything seems so easy, so unreal .. that doesn´t make them bad, but you know .. it does not fit with the reality. 
This show in theother hand, represents pretty well those things. The action feels real, everything runs so natural, so smooth and at the same time it is inspiring. 


BUT... there is a huge fucking problem ... it's boring as hell. Yeah .. i took 2 weeks to watch 36 episodes.. 


Story: 8/10. It is just a slice life, but as i said, it looks so natural that i can´t give less than 8/10. The pace is kinda slow, since the evolution of the characters takes a while even though the actual time in the anime moves pretty fast, the entire action if i'm not in mistake takes 4 years, instead of the classical 1 year. But this is a josei, so it's more like a comedy/romance for adults. I felt while i was watching this show, that some of the themes talked about there were just to complicated for me, because i'm just 17 years old and i didn´t even started my life yet, so if you are in the same position, get ready because some parts may be confusing(i mean we can´t understand well what is going on, or i'm just dumb..) I believe, for those who seek mature themes, this is the ONE ! 


Art: 6/10. WHAT A PAIN ! The characters look extremely bad... like really bad. Usually i always find a character that draws my attention.. like Akame in Akame Ga Kill .. here i did not find such thing. The characters look rough and their own design for me, it´s not well made. I've seen a lot better from older animes. So there is no excuse. 


Although the background saves the day, it is not detailed, but when it comes to represent the feelings of the characters, or to make a nice mood, does it extremely well. 


Sound: 8/10. The openings are okay. What really calls my attention is the musics that they use in the episodes .. yes musics not OST(OST for who doesn´t know, is the music to fill the silence..) here we actually have like endings in the middle of the shows .. some of them are brilliant, makes the end of the scene much more better. 


Character: 9/10. One thing my friends .. DEPTH .. like the depth of the ocean , it goes even further. I mean, there are 5 main characters here. Each one gets a nice development, and we get to know everything about them. Usually i only see this kind of thing in 2 characters at top.. here there are 5. But the payment is extremely high, i will explain later on. 


Back to the characters, like i said at the beginning, i almost grant you that you will find one character that fits with your personality.. all of them are great characters and it's nice seeing their "evolution" throughout the show. 


The supportive characters also get a nice development.. the one that works with our main character at his job? Well she gets development .. technically, everyone that gets with one of our main characters has some kind of development... really impressive seeing how far this anime goes in terms of development. 


Enjoyment: 7/10. The first season is really slow because of the development. I mean the development is good but at the same time it makes the anime really boring at some times.. the rest is nice. The romance is good, it sounds natural you know .. and that is really a important thing. The drama is also great so as the inspiring lessons about life that this anime gives to us. 


Overall : For the first season: 6.5/10. For the second season : 8/10. For who likes romances, give this one a try. For who likes romances, but only those cute romances like toradora or so .. well this one is not the right for you. I would say that while toradora is too childish, this one is too mature so it may not be of your satisfaction.

Was it ever supposed to get this good? Honey and Clover began life as the debut series for Fuji TV's "Noitamina" (read it backwards) lineup, a new anime block aimed at older female audiences. The simple but daring plan worked—young women who would never normally watch anime got into it, and the manga now breaks the Top 10 sales list regularly, sitting alongside blockbuster titles like Prince of Tennis or Bleach. But even viewers outside the target demographic attest to its greatness, pointing out its heartfelt storytelling and unique visual style. It was supposed to be just good enough for sophisticated female viewers—and it endedup being good enough for everyone. Funnier than most comedies and more touching than most dramas (even the live-action ones), Honey and Clover has emerged as one of the best shows of 2005.


Like a true slice-of-life series, it begins right in the middle of things—Takemoto in his second year of college, Mayama nearing graduation, and Morita stuck in seventh-year hell. When Hagu-chan shows up, there's hardly any "please welcome the new student" pomp; she simply joins the cast, and the drama-go-round begins. There is no epic quest to fulfill, no convoluted conspiracy to unlock, no childhood friend to win over—it's just a bunch of college kids figuring out what to do with their lives, and it is fascinating. Every character gets a moment in the spotlight, with story arcs transiting flawlessly between each other. Even Takemoto, who spends most of the series as a neutral observer, closes things out with an inspiring personal triumph. The mood of the show switches effortlessly from madcap comedy to utter heartbreak and everything in between, yet nothing feels out of place. Within a single episode, a game of Art School Twister takes humor to new heights, and yet minutes later, Takemoto muses upon the meaning of friendship.


Like all good shoujo, Honey and Clover succeeds because of its characters' complex personalities. Morita emerges as a quick fan favorite with his bizarre antics and affinity for money, but to focus on him is to miss out on the intricate relationships between everyone else. In particular, Ayumi's unrequited attachment to Mayama is sure to arouse plenty of indignation about the portrayal of women in Japanese entertainment. But maybe that anger is because Ayumi openly reveals everything we hate about themselves: weakness, insecurity, and the tendency to do really stupid things in the name of love. She is the most human character in a cast of incredibly human characters.


Despite this realism on the emotional level, however, the artwork in the show is decidedly surreal and dreamlike. The character designs match the manga almost perfectly with big, expressive eyes, ultrathin lines, and characteristic hatch marks. Even the coloring style adheres to the comic; you may never again see an anime that looks like it was watercolored (there are a few exceptions, like SaiKano). The animation is equally adept, with moments of broad physical comedy being rendered just as smoothly as subtle scenes of close-up dialogue. And of course, no discussion of Honey and Clover is complete without the infamous "food" opening, where spinning plates of food behave in very un-foodlike ways. This 90-second homage to stop-motion auteur Jan Svankmajer is just the first of many artistic touches, proving that the animators—like the art students depicted in the series—treasure creativity above all else.


If music is the language of emotion, then few shows speak it as eloquently as this one. With just a few studio instruments, the soundtrack is able to express the gamut of emotions that each character runs through. The energetic opening theme by YUKI converts into a gentle piano solo, and even Morita's bouts of insanity are accented by charming comedic themes. The most effective emotional tools, however, are the insert songs by singer-songwriter Suga Shikao and rock group SPITZ. Playing a poignant song over internal monologue is hardly a new thing, especially in angsty teen dramas, but to hear it used in an anime makes the technique fresh once more.


If Honey and Clover has any faults, it's that you want it to keep going after it's over. It ends just like it begins—right in the middle of things, with so much more yet to be experienced. Without realizing it, you've become part of that circle of friends: you've shared their heartbreaks and triumphs, walked alongside them as they poured out their feelings, and watched each one of them learn a little bit more about themselves. Whether in school or not, who hasn't asked themselves at some point: "What do I want to do? Who do I want to be?" Honey and Clover may not have the answers, but it's all about trying to find them.
