I can easily tell you that Honey and Clover is and will remain my most favorite anime of all time. 
Story
Honey and Clover's story is so simple. It's a story about some friends who are attending the same art college....and pretty much what they go through in their everyday college student lives. At first glance, oh it's bland. Where's the action? Where's the crazy plot twists? Where's the fan service?? Where's the blatant mushy romance?!?!?
*cough* I see why this anime is a tad underrated.*cough*
This anime is SUBTLE,  SO subtle, in its storytelling. It doesn't lay everything out for you in plain writing. It unfoldsgradually, maturing slowly. It gives you hints--glimpses, snippets, of a character's true feelings, strivings, yearnings-- a glimmer of what's really there underneath the plots' seemingly simplistic surface. The development of the story is pretty unique as well. This story is essentially about love. Painful love. Giddy love. Unrequited love. Life changing love. But mostly about the care and devotion that we feel towards our friends. And so the plot isn't developed with unexpected happenings or crazy tragedy or predictable romance. It's developed as the relationships between the characters develop. Which is incredible.What I LOVE about the story is that it isn't plastered with those cheap devices one finds in a lot of anime to keep the viewers' attention (fanservice, cutesy romance, melodrama, fast plot with zillions of littles arcs).\n
 It is SO honest with the story it's trying to tell. So genuine. So straight forward yet deeply moving and suggestive of things so much bigger than what it shows you. In the end, you're left breathless.\n
 It's just...so beautiful. \n\n
Art\n
The art matches the tone and style of this series PERFECTLY. It's muted and pastelly and soft and seems to glow a bit. It might seem boring to some. It isn't jam-packed with CGI and bold colors and crisp backgrounds. But it's beautiful all the same. I loved the unique sugary softness of the character designs especially.\n\n
Sound\n
The music for this series was another home run. Like the art (and everything else) it fit the series perfectly. I also really liked the opening and ending songs :)\n\n
Character\n
The characters of Honey and Clover are what make this anime a masterpiece. Like any story, character development is key. What I liked so much about this anime was how realistic the characters were. The emotions they feel and they way they react to the situations they go through were just so believable. I could relate to so much of it. And as the anime progresses and you get to see more and more of who these characters are, you grow to understand the way they feel and why they act they way they do....you get to see what makes them tick is a way. Watching the characters of this series grow and develop and mature and relate to one another, the connections they build, and the love that they share, is an incredible experience.\n\n
Enjoyment/Overall: \n
Honey and Clover, to me, is an incredible anime because it's unique, the character development is... incredible, it's very touching and heart warming...but mostly because it's so sincere with the story it's trying to tell. It sticks to the integrity of the storytelling and its central themes of love and friendship in a way that's so genuine and lovely and passionate...I don't see how it couldn't be my favorite anime.

Overall	
Not really what I had expected. Kind of a love drama with some comedy, but instead of focussing on the love and relationships, it explores human thoughts and behaviour that stands in the way of those things. And I like that twist on this classic thteme.
This anime makes you reflect about your own life, which it an impressive feat. But the story itself is fractured and pretty hard to keep track of. It probably should have been compressed into 13 episodes. There is not THAT much going on.
Cute, funny and philosophical on a first-person level. Not bad at all.
The OVA's episode 25 and 26 ("F"& "L") are just four irrelevant comedy scetches, and not really worth watching if you have a life.\n\n
Animation	\n
Looking pretty neat. Great character design yadda yadda. I think I have said this about like 90% of the animes I've watched. But still, neat.\n\n
Sound	\n
The opening and ending themes are not my cup of tea, and the background music is very, veery repetetive. The voice acting is good, though, but as usual in anime there is one voice you just can't stand (Hagu in this case).\n\n
Story	\n
There are several storylines going on at the same time, and it gets hard to keep track of them all. Often it just feels very fractured, when the directors try to jam as much stuff into each episode as possible. But still the story moves at a very slow pace. And do we get closure? Not really. It all moves on in the 2nd season though.\n\n
Character	\n
The main cast is a diverse lot, and most are involved in at least one love triangle and a couple of other plotlines. Not many of these get very evolved, and I guess you could say character development on a linear time scale is pretty nonexistant. But you still get to know most of the cast pretty deep somehow. And they are all brilliant!

Based on both seasons of H&C
This anime is definitely NOT for everyone. I was drawn to this anime simply because of the overwhelming craze/awards/hype it was getting. A friend told me this anime had a girl in it that went beyond the Lolita look and was fancied by the male characters in the series and even though they where all 18+ of age it made him (and me at times) feel awkward.
At the end of the day I (unfortunately) have to agree with the majourity and say this is a very good anime show overall.
Animation 
Animation was decent, character animation was different than casual animewith face shapes and stuff but the scenery was drawn beautifully, one of the major strong points of this anime. Ending scene was nice as well especially in the first season.


Sound 


Another shining point for the anime, Opening for 1st season was a bit Up-tempo but nice. Character voices were perfect, everyone seemed to fit well even if it was annoying at times (Hagu). Generally the sound just fit very well with the flow of things.


Story


This is the difficult part. I said earlier this anime isn’t for everyone that’s because with these “Real Life” type stories it comes down to what part of real life us the viewers want to see. Now this is definitely a drama/romance anime but I personally wouldn’t class this as girly because it wasn’t girly at all. Yes I will say there is a soap-opera feel which can annoy at times but it is balanced out quite well never going too “sunset beach” if you will. Every character had their own personal issues as well as love problems which mixed well with their college life, work and ambitions. The most surprising part of this story is that it is spanned over a number of years so you see just how fast or slow life can change around you. In retrospect looking at this as a story it is well written and very realistic but some people might find this slow paced and eventless….well sometimes life can seem that way I guess.


Character


Characters are excellent. When I first watched this anime I was really pessimistic in thinking all these other reviewers where just being too nice or something. By the time I got half way through season one I noticed that the characters where quite mature and interesting. I felt a “School Rumble” type vibe from some of the characters especially Morita. These characters make the story what it is and I must say while some might annoy you with their problems (Ayumi) others will gain your respect (Takemoto).


Enjoyment


Uhm I felt a higher sense of intrigue then enjoyment foe this title.

I did enjoy this anime to a point and im glad I watched it overall as it reminded me of the main reason I love anime, which is to enjoy a great story that will get me thinking. So i guess I can understand now why this got such high praise.


Value 


Value is probably the lowest point. Although this anime is a great story in itself I do admit I found it hard to watch most of the time. Maybe it’s because after a certain point I was more focused on some characters rather than others or maybe at times the love issues annoyed me. Either way, now I’ve watched it I can say it was a good story overall about people and the lives and choices they made but watching it again would definitely not happen.


In a way it just like real life once its gone there’s no going back.

Honey and Clover is a very unique anime and I would definitely recommend it to those who enjoy watching a ''different'' plot . H and C rates high in my anime rankings. It showcased a grand production, from the art, music, character, story and most of all... the talks.
In H and C, the talks are not just random mumble jumble between characters.. It served as a bridge connecting the characters and provided an emotional atmosphere that pervades and certainly is the hallmark of this anime.
The characters are certainly memorable.. with their own quirks which I found cute and some troubling. Each has his/her own uniqueness stamped and is edible throughout the show.
One thing that always comes to mind when I think of Honey and Clover is the conversationbetween Mayama and Yamada. Mayama was taking Ayu home and she was quite drunk.. she then said..\n\n
“Mayama…suki….daisuki….Mayama!!!..suki!….Daisuki!!!…Mayama! Suki!…(Okay)… Daisuki!…(Arigato)”\n\n
Bitter-sweet. It was certainly bitter-sweet.

You know how a scenery, a song, or even a smell can be so nostalgic that it takes you to those carefree and happy days which you reminiscence when you are going through some hard times? Well this anime, at least to me, was that scenery, that song, and that smell. 
I watched this anime when I was in Uni back in 2009. At that time I didn't think too much of it, just another slice of life anime. But something compelled me to watch it again and boy am I glad I did. After a few jobs and that one relationship this show reallyfeels completely different. I can really see the suitableness and nuance of being a young adult. You know, the time in your life when you come to a grinding stop after years of school because you always "knew" that you had to get a good education or years of living someone else's dreams and ambitions, what commonly is known as a quarter life crisis. This show, simultaneously makes you rethink the choices you have made in life and gives you hope for the future. Because no one is  perfect and you don't always get what you want or what you think is fair in life. Maybe I am reading to much into the story or I am forcing my own experience on the narrative. Whatever it is, this show reminded me that you have to continue with life and enjoy everything that it throws at you. 


The ending theme 'Waltz' will always have a place in my heart as the song that reminds me of this beautiful anime and that not all mistakes are bad.

I really wanted to like H&C. It's widely spoken of as a classic and a must-see for those who like romantic animes. It focuses around 5 college students who I found mostly likable and realistic, but i couldn't stand the portrayal of one of the characters - Hagumi. 
She's this 10-year-old looking kid who babbles incoherently, cries easily, hides behind her friends when there's strangers (and she's supposed to be 18). And a big part of the show is how others deal with their attraction towards her, and how she deals with her own romantic feelings.
It's just asking me to believe too much. This girlis supposed to be sexually mature and desirable? She acts like a ten year old but somehow knows the concept of love?\n\n
It just feels too much like lolicon. I have to drop it.

Now Honey & Clover, well what can I say what's different from all the others, I'll tell you this is one of those Anime which you watch episode one and think "I'm not sure" so I'll watch Ep2, then Ep3, and then it's I'm still not sure, so I'll watch a few more tommorow by then your hooked!!
I was unsure firstly as it is quite extreme emoitions it's more like a comic then a anime but it becomes like a soap and once you get to know the characters a bit then you will love it. The only weird bit is the fact that Hagu-Chanis supposed to be about 18 but looks like a 11 yr old girl in appearance & actions, and two of the other male college students think their in love with her.


The thing is everytime i think this isn't for me, there seems to be a really nice bits that keep you feeling good.


Recommended.

Honey and Clover, it's a shoujo title some might say but the truth is that this anime transcends labels and genres and becomes one of the most enjoyable animes I've ever had the pleasure to watch.
This story is often narrated by Takemoto, a young boy that is studying at an art school, however the primary focus of this series isn't just Takemoto, it's the whole group of people around him, and that makes Honey and Clover shine more than anything else.
Honey and Clover juggles between comedy and heart wrenching drama with some brushes of nostalgia and teenage angst, making a combination that will make youunable to be emotionless.


You wonder about the fate of the characters and feel with them, making oneself look at their own lives much more that they think. This isn't an anime about romance/drama, is mostly about life and growing up. A coming of age story if you will.


For individual aspects:


Story 10: Simple but deep, the story altough has a pretty basic formula gets complex when you analyze each and every character and the relationships with each other, allowing you to be surprised. This is where Honey and Clover shines.


Art: The art is great, clean animation and beautiful sceneries. Has a dream-like feel to it, as well as breath-taking when it comes to country-side Japan.


Sound: The insert songs by Spitz, Suneohair, and the Opening by Yuki bring out the emotion from scenes and moments, turning them into heartwrenching moments that will be burned into your head. The music in H&C is down-right amazing.


Characters: Another strong point, every character has it's own personality and doesn't fall to clichés. At the start one may classify some characters, but as the series progress so the characters. There isn't one unlovable character in this series.


Enjoyment: From smart and laugh out funny moments, to gut-wrenching drama, to heart warming love this series has it all.


Overall: 9/10 The only reason I don't give this anime a 10 is because of the pace. The anime has a good pace but sometimes it's broken with some slice-of-life episodes that make the pacing go awkward for a bit.

For both the seasons:
The description feels like nothing compared to the anime. Though it is correct, the anime offers a lot more.
At first I wasn't expecting much. The animation was kind of different, and I was not used to such a setting. The characters were not introduced in the usual manner. It felt random. But after watching a few episodes, it started getting interesting. If you are a slice of life lover, this one is a must.
The anime was quite mature in handling relationships. After watching a hundred romance anime in school setting, it was definitely worth watching and gave me a good change.
The humorwas pretty good. I never expected to have a good laugh in between quite serious scenes. There were sad moments, moments which made you think about your own life, moments when you would try to understand love and a lot more.\n\n
As in the description, even though you may not be poor, any college student living on his/her own has a lot to relate to. The confusion about what to do in life, friends, love, talent, work are portrayed beautifully.\n\n
Overall, Hachimitsu to Clover is anime worth watching and enjoyable. I went through both the seasons in a single go, though I was hesitant in the beginning. So, give it a try and you will love it.  \n\n

My problem with the "slice of life" genre is that it is very hard to relate to the character in those shows. Just like how Fist of North Star have over-the-top violent, "slice of life" tend to suffer from over-the-top peace and happiness. 
Hachimitsu to Clover have none of those problem. The characters in the show faced a lot of realistic problem. Young people have endless opportunity in front of them, but at the same time it bring the same amount of doubt and anxiety.
The main character (MC), being not specially talented at anything, is surrounded by a cast of super talented friend with brightfuture ahead of them. Setting the standard of "satisfying career" even harder for the MC. Now mix in some romance, love triangle, drama, job-hunter, and graduation closer and closer.\n\n
The story is presented with a great dose of comedy, with beautify graphic style that resemble oil painting, a perfect match for a show that set in a art college. \n\n
Hachimitsu to Clover is one awesome bittersweet journey, something that only happened once in anyone's life time. The show doesn't have any tear-jerking moment, but I know I shed some tears at the end.

The Sweet aspect of Love
Honey and Clover is a Romantic Dramatic Comedy were emotions run high, comedy hits hard and watchers may be reduced to tears (Including Me Many Times).
Story 9/10
The story seems familiar at the beginning, the main character meets a girl, who looks older than she actually looks and is coincidentally amazing at art. But everything beyond that is fresh and new including every situation within the show; you’ll never know what will happen next. The Romance has enough fuzzy feelings to carbonate the ocean 3 times over.  It may progress slowly and you may feel like you have it mapped outbut than it takes a completely different turn. The drama is in abundance, many main characters suffer when things don’t go their way. When The Comedy does appear it is quite well 

needed and flat out, gut bustingly hilarious (THANK YOU MORITA-SAN!).


Characters 10/10


Honey and Clover produces some of the most memorable and lovable characters of all time. Every character progresses GREATLY within the show.


Takemoto is a 19 year old college student living in the some house as his best friends Morita and Mayama. He is very mellow and is quite the likable dude. He soon acts as a big-brother figure to Hagumi, always being there for her and always ready to help her.


Hagumi is a cute 18 year old girl with the appearance of a small child. She is very skilled in art but is shy and very nervous when conversing with those she does not know.


Morita is a happy go lucky 24 year old 6 time student. He is very comedic and mysterious, randomly showing up and leaving the household. 75% of all the comedy comes from Morita’s insanity or crazy situations which are very swell


Mayama is the “normal” one. Being nice and always helpful is this man’s strong suit. He is very caring towards his friends


Ayumi is a well-known ceramic artist, making fast friends with Hagumi because of her kind nature


Many more side characters come into play but all of them are well handled and lovable.


Art: 10/10


The Art is AMAZING; everything appears with a water color like hue, the character design is cute and all are reminiscent of the characters personality. The Openings especially is beyond beautiful, one being done with stop motion food and the other being animated.


Sound: 9/10


The VA cast is lively and captures characters perfectly. The Opening and background music is a well-made treat.


Overall 9/10


It may start out slowly but gains speed. If you like to Laugh, Cry, and Wonder what the Hell is coming next; HONEY AND CLOVER is the show for you.

This review is based off of both season 1 and season 2 of honey and clover. (I have bad grammar, but review will be spoiler free)
STORY:
The story is about a group of art college students who become friends and live there lives. That is the story in simple terms. The story also has some twist. For example there are a couple of love triangles, and a few other small annoying factors in the story that are not a huge deals, but they still plays a toll on the story.
ART:
As I am sure the majority of us are well aware, but for those who are notthe art is very well done considering the anime was only aired in 2005. Even if the art is actually considered "bad" in my opinion it is perfect. It matches the story to a T, and for some reason makes the story feel.as if it were on a more emotional level. 


SOUND: 

I didn't notice the sound much throughout the anime, however when there was a scene that was supposed to be emotional or dramatic the sound was for the most part on point, and really emphasized the emotional aspect of whatever scene it was in the anime. (Dramatic scenes for the most part )


CHARACTER:

 If ir weren't for the main fact that my favorite character was rejected by a.certain someone in the anime in the second last episode I would probably gave a higher rating, but I waited for the very moment when she would NOT reject him, but she decided to reject him even though she "loved him" and holy moly I wish it were different. Anyway enough with the rambling. The characted development was consistent throughout the anime, and each character had  something to overcome,  and I feel no characters was left out. I will admit some characters should have been focused on more than others, but in the end they managed to make most of the characters instady thoughts come to a stable point where they could end the anime. I realize that may not make much sense but basically the characters thoughts and feelings came to a point at the end where they could be happy simply put. 


OVERALL/ENJOYMENT

Overall I really enjoyed the anime. Especially the romance aspects of it. Even though there was more drama than romance.  My favorite character was also at the very least recognized and loves my the one girl I wanted him to end up with, however they did not end up together so that made me enjoy the anime a little less. I recommend anyone who likes romance. Of drama to give it a go. Again this review is based on both seasons.

Nodame Cantabile is one of the most popular shows ever. It's a manga that got turned into an anime, TV show, and movie. In my mind it's quite similar to HachiKuro, which is a manga that got turned into an anime, TV show, and movie. I'd bet NodaCan is the more popular of the two but did you know Yoko Kanno did the music for the HachiKuro movie?
In order to write this review, I watched the first two episodes just now. I last saw the entire show nearly ten years ago. @_@ All I remembered was that it was very emotional, most of the characters’names, certain plot points, that it was beautiful, and that they liked to put songs into the episodes. I’m waiting to find someone who might be interested in this show before I re-watch the whole thing, so this will have to suffice. Why did I decide to write a review of HachiKuro? Firstly, I promised Karlstein I would (before I got sidetracked). Secondly, I wanted to put a positive review in my reviews.


I’ll tell you a secret. I love art. What struck me when I first saw the show was just how good it looked. It seemed less of an anime and more of a watercolor manga come to life, with its soft colors and detailed lines. Watching it today, I noticed it was more than that. The way shots are framed is also quite impressive, with varied angles and distances appropriate for the mood.


Morita-sempai! He’s awesome. One thing that bugged me about the Viz subs is that even though they put -sempai and stuff on names and have a glossary of cultural terms, some weirdo decided to always put characters’ first names. Shinobu? I totally forgot he had a first name.


HachiKuro is about art students making art, and some of the pieces they come up with are really neat. At the same time, they have to deal with growing up and relationships, hence it being very emotional. The characters act believably towards each other, although certain things are exaggerated, like when Hagu cries, her eyes become squiggles or Morita-sempai zooms around at high speed. There’s a certain light mood through the show, which helps to you become attached to the characters and ratchets up the drama higher than an entirely serious show would be able to. This is a delicate balance to maintain. Too much humor can devalue the serious parts but they pull it off magnificently.


As far as I can recall, there aren’t many sword fights, giant mech races, or space ship battles, so if you’re looking for action, I’m afraid you may be in for some disappointment. What you have is beautiful art, and stories of friendship and love. I once showed someone “Whisper of the Heart” and she thought it was incredibly boring because it seemed like all very normal, everyday stuff. This is rather along those lines.


I remember the first time I saw this show. I accidentally walked in on episode three or four and thought it looked really dumb. However, I eventually went back, started from the top, and let it draw me in. Ack, that pun was not intended.


A few months ago, I borrowed the movie version from the library and watched a little bit. However, since they only had 116 minutes to cover (presumably) season one, everything got jumbled and they had to slot famous lines in wherever they could. Also, Hagu was too tall.

Honey and Clover has an extremely unique art style. Studio J.C. Staff from works like Revolutionary Girl Utena and Slayers at this point never tackled an anime of such maturity before. This show was directed by the amazing Kenichi Kasia (Major), so hope were scattered going in. Could a studio that has never really handled this kind of show before pull out a winner? Could a good director save the show and make the audience fall in love with each character?
Yuuta Takemoto is an art major trying to find his motivation in life, but seems to go about his daily routine in a lull. Helives a simple life and joins with: a serious guy by the name of Takumi, a dude that is like a living energy drink called Shinobu, a small petite 18 years art talent named Hagumi, and Hagumi’s friend Ayu. All of these characters go through important and interesting trials in their college lives ranging from falling in love, moving on from tough times, and discovering one’s self.


To make this show into something great it is very clear how important the direction of specific voice acting, aesthetics, following a tight script, and making it all believable simultaneously. Honey and Clover’s best success comes from the characters. The chemistry between each of the main cast never over exaggerates, but instead creates an environment that the audience can relate to. Due to the fact there is not a distinct plot, these same characters must push the show through each and every episode. Never is there a trope or cliché to detach from reality, but each person is intelligent, has their own individuality, their own emotions never to be wasted at any point or in any scene. Speaking of emotions, when there is a heart wrenching moment or fear be it longing for love or acceptance, the audience can’t help but feel the same emotions as that particular character which creates real personalities. It is like we, the audience, can hear those character’s screams for love they will never have returned to them. Honey and Clover is very powerful in that sense.


Light piano music with various J-pop molds well within the drama unfolding. The music even creates a nice transition between events and scenes never feeling forced. Animation is in a pastel art which can deter some from the show along with a slower pace, but this actually helps the show. Slower movement of scenes creates active tension for the characters, and gives the audience time to slowly realize that single emotion a characters is feeling. Along with that soft piano, a sense of calmness after all of the emotional trials comes over the atmosphere that isn’t really experienced in many anime. Almost everything about Honey and Clover is unique.


This anime does a fantastic job making what could seem like a generic college romance story on the surface turn into something more with unforgettable characters going about their daily lives without being dull. Unfortunately, this leads to an ending without a real conclusion much like real life. Very few events are totally resolved, but by the end of Honey and Clover, it would be hard to not relate to at least one character.

I try to keep things short and sweet:
OUTSTANDING 'slice of life' anime focused on superbly fleshed out characters and their relationships as they grow from a group of young adults into individuals in their own right.  The characters themselves are what make this anime such a success, and Honey and Clover does an excellent job of fluidly giving each individual enough screen time to shine.  The themes and conflicts are very easy to relate to, and the story moves along in a soft, but surprisingly slippery pace-- as does life at that age.
It's touching, heartfelt, at times bittersweet, with just the right amountof comedy.  The animation style is a little bit different, but works very well considering the subject matter IMO.\n\n
BONUS:  If you're an artist, writer, or have a creative mind, the running theme concerning struggles with inspiration and creativity in general will really hit home.  Highly recommended.

Honey & Clover was the most pleasant surprise I had in the past few months or so. I really didn't expect it to be THAT good.
Both the characters and the relationship between them are outstanding. I can't think of a flat character among the main ones (Takemoto, Morita, Hagu, Yamada, Mayama and Shuji), they are all round and well made. It's hard no to see yourself in a lot of situations.
How these people get along during the challenges that appear during college days and some love triangles take the most part of the show. An odd thing is that to me the lead character (Takemoto)was rather uninteresting until the end of the first season.\n\n
The soundtrack also stands out in Honey & Clover. Right in the first episode there is a remarkable scene with the OST. The OP-ED are unusually good, with some references of the anime itself (as usual) and other movies/series, like Beetlejuice, which is very interesting.\n\n
I'd recomend it to anyone, one of my favorite animes.

Short reviewer here. Hachimitsu to Clover is a great anime for those who wishes to view slice of life, drama and comedy. Romance is part of this anime but isn't really significant. I was pretty hesitant to watch this at first due to it being labeled as women's anime. However, I'm glad to have experienced Hachimitsu to Clover. I experienced all kinds of emotions while watching this anime. 
(Side note: I've read reviews claiming how this anime is so "boring" and slow paced. WHAT THE HECK DID YOU EXPECT? ACTION??? Don't come bashing this anime when you don't like watching slice of life, drama, andcomedy.This anime isn't for little kids with premature brains.)


The story is great.


The art is okay, its different from those generic drawing/animations. 


THE SOUND REALLY MAKES THIS ANIME FANTASTIC! Oh man I love the soundtrack.


Characters are incredibly lovable. I've laughed and felt depressed with them.


I enjoyed this anime and I'm sure you will too. Please don't rate this low just because your young and haven't experienced real conflicts/emotions.

This review is for both of the seasons of Honey & Clover.
Overall, I think that this story is a masterpiece. I don't like "slice-of-life" genre AT ALL, but this story certainly captured me... even though I thought I would hate it. 
The characters are not cardboard at all. They come to life, they have their own problems & in the end, it seems like there isn't just one "main character", but there are many. Their personal lives really suck you in. Every character develops into a new person it seems by the end of the series.
The drama is good, but it seems to take severalepisodes sometimes for one character to get over a certain problem. This was probably the only thing that bothered me.\n\n
The animation is pretty good. Sometimes backgrounds can seem generic & overused, but other times, the animation can take your breath away.\n\n
If you're looking for romance, an anime with a reality check, sadness, happiness & definitely a lot of comedy, this anime is for you & is definitely worth a shot!

Art school + life and all its discoveries is what Honey and clover is about.
It is a truly beautiful anime, which combines the paths we take in life with the funny little anime moment we all love.
One of the things I found truly amazing was the depth and differences in character. Each person has their own hidden secrets and tendencies, their own feelings. I loved the way the characters grew before my eyes throughout the series and I want to keep following their journeys after this series and the next had finished.
Another thing I found very amazing was how they realistically portrayed feelings, loveand unrequited love. In most shows these are not portrayed as realistically as you would like, and, even it is romantic, it doesn't grasp how you would feel if you were in there shoes. However, for me, Honey and Clover does an excellent job of this, I really felt like I had gone through what they were going through, and I would sit there and go, 'that is exactly how I would feel.'\n\n
This anime really captures you and allows you to follow and wish to be part of this story, but it also allows to not want to be part of the story and instead, just watch.\n

_Honey and Clover_ was odd. I *wanted* to like it, but for some reason it just struck me as mediocre. I was going to leave it at 7, but I thought the final episodes developed Takemoto's character at least a little, and I was deeply amused by the comedy interlude episodes ('Ham-senpai!'); as well, I have a lingering fondness for the visual elegance & music of the first ED. I'd like to see where the characters go, so I'll watch season 2.
